marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Lawyer, Secretary of the Navy (1841); U.S. Senator from North Carolina (1846-1855); resident of Raleigh (Wake County) and New Bern (Craven County), N.C.

Personal and business letters. Most letters are to Thomas Mandeville Carlisle concerning family and business matters, especially a disagreement between the Postmaster General and the railroads. A letter to R.B. Temple refers to Zachary Taylor's election. Also includes a commonplace book of Frances L. Badger containing original poetry.
Correspondence of Herbert T. Bacon, of his family, and of the Gregory family, concerning amusements and courtships. One letter, May 14, 1846, analyzes the progress of the Mexican War.
Alabama resident (Monroe County) and U.S. Senator.
Letter from Benjamin Fitzpatrick to Bagby requesting a naval appointment for a friend.

Legal papers, letters and manuscript articles, primarily built around the lives and careers of Aylett, a resident of Richmond, Virginia, and his son-in-law, William Lawrence Royall, and focusing on the Civil War. Several items concern the capture of Royall by Union troops in March 1865.
Letter recording the activities of Electus Backus, Sr. in the War of 1812.
Farmer, mechanic, and Confederate soldier, from Iredell County, N.C.
Chiefly correspondence between Baggarly and his wife, Nancy. Baggarly's letters discuss the war, camp life, diseases, and deserters. Nancy's letters reflect the hardships faced by soldiers' wifes.
Virginia resident, author, and editor of the SOUTHERN LITERARY MESSENGER.

Letter from R.B. Rhett, Jr., expressing hope that Bagby will reestablish his connection with the Charleston MERCURY, and attacking the military policy of Jefferson Davis; a letter from an unidentified friend in Lynchburg, Virginia, dealing with personal and local matters; and a letter from Edward S. Joynes concerning the circulation of a brief biography of Dr. Harrison, a University of Virginia professor.
Resident of Georgia and Confederate major general.
Two letters from Bagley to his sister on his resignation from the U.S. Army and on conditions at Fort Pulaski, Georgia.
Enlisted ranks (private, sgt., sgt. maj.), then 2d Lt. (1865) in the 9th Ohio Cavalry.

Civil War diary (ca. 110 pp.) of Axline, a sergeant in Co. A, 9th Ohio Cavalry Regiment at the time of writing, including service in Ohio (Camp Chase, Zanesville, and Camp Dennison) and in Kentucky (Lexington, Richmond, London, Manchester, Barbourville, Williamsburg, Pine Mountain, and Cumberland River). There are descriptions of military action against small Confederate unites and guerillas in southeastern Kentucky, and of camp life.
Residents of Hartford, Conn., and Thibodaux, La.

Chiefly letters from Philip Bacon to his family in Hartford Co., Connecticut. The letters concern cotton farming; freedmen as laborers; emancipation of slaves; war news; and local reaction to Union occupation. Correspondence from 1866 is from E.H. Bissell, Northern businessman; one letter contains a copy of letter from ex-Confederate relative who chastizes his Northern kin. Subjects in these letters include the Charlotte, N.C. mint and condition of N.C. economy.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession record.

Miscellaneous letters, one from Ayres to General George Gordon Meade acknowledging his appointment as a major general and three to Mrs. Ayres (Juliet Opie Hopkins Butcher) from John M. Schofield and Daniel E. Sickles.

Diary of a trip made by Avery and his wife travelling by steamboat, railroad, and stagecoach from New Orleans to Washington, D.C. He describes the cities of Mobile, Montgomery, Macon, Savannah, Jacksonville (Fla.), Charleston, Wilmington, Richmond, and Washington, among others. Along the way he met Mayor Gustavus Horton of Mobile and Governor Robert M. Patton of Alabama, discussing with them the progress of Reconstruction; and author and diplomat John Bigelow. He also attended services at African American Methodist churches in Mobile and Charleston; and saw freedmen in the Catholic cathedral in Mobile.
Washington, D.C. resident and U.S. Navy rear admiral.
Letter from Bailey to his nephew, T. Bailey Myers, about Admiral Farragut's retraction of his criticism of Bailey's leadership in the Battle of Mobile in 1864.
U.S. Army officer, aide-de-camp, and private secretary to U.S. Grant.
Letter from Babcock to H.A. Spaulding concerning personal business matters. Letter from Joseph Hayne Rainey to Babcock concerning a list of men attending a convention in South Carolina.
Family correspondence of a planter in the vicinity of Whitakers (Nash Co.), N.C., who lived for a time in Texas. Topics include personal matters and farm management.
Letter to A. P. Sawyer regarding the purchase of stock in the Atlantic and Danville Railway Company.
Georgia resident and member of the U.S. Senate.
One letter deals with Georgia politics in 1886. There is printed material on the funeral service for Bacon in 1914 in the U.S. Senate Chamber.
Baptist minister, of Plymouth (Washington Co.), N.C.
Accusations and evidence against Babb charging him with misconduct and misappropriation of funds. Mentioned in the correspondence are Columbus Durham, D.E. Riddick Jr., and R.T. Vann.

A letter from Baggs to Henry Pickney McCain, Adjutant General of the United States; McCain's reply; and a letter from John McElroy, editor of Washington, D.C.'s National Tribune, to Baggs, concerning Civil War statistics.
